sections.title: Why Reticulum
sections.content:
Every communication system you rely on has a single point of failure. Cell towers. Internet service providers. DNS servers. Government kill switches. When infrastructure goes down—through disaster, conflict, or deliberate action—so does your ability to coordinate, share intelligence, or call for help.

Reticulum eliminates these dependencies. It creates encrypted mesh networks over whatever physical medium is available: a $35 LoRa radio, an HF transceiver, a WiFi router, or all of them simultaneously. No accounts. No servers. No permissions. If two devices can exchange bits, they can form a Reticulum network.

Bottom Line: Reticulum gives you sovereign communications. You control the network because you ARE the network.

sections.title: What It Actually Does
sections.content:
Reticulum handles three problems that normally require infrastructure:

1. Identity Without Registration

Your identity is a cryptographic keypair generated locally. No email, no phone number, no account creation. Share your public destination hash and anyone can send you encrypted messages. Lose your device? Generate a new identity in seconds.

2. Routing Without Servers

Messages find their destination through a gossip protocol. Each node remembers where it heard about other nodes. No routing tables, no central directory. The network self-heals as nodes join and leave.

3. Encryption Without Trust

Every link uses ephemeral keys negotiated via X25519 ECDH. Even if someone captures your traffic today, they can't decrypt it tomorrow. No certificates, no certificate authorities, no trust decisions.

sections.title: What You Can Build
sections.content:
Messaging (LXMF)

Encrypted messages that work like email but over any transport. Messages store-and-forward through propagation nodes when recipients are offline. Works over LoRa at 300 bps or fiber at gigabit speeds—same protocol.

Information Nodes (NomadNet)

Host pages and files accessible to anyone on the network. Think websites, but they work over HF radio. The LFM node at 2eabad04f9145d32a6a3eda285d66c39 hosts articles, tools, and a chat room bridged to Matrix—all accessible from a terminal over mesh.

Custom Applications

Build anything that needs secure point-to-point communication. File transfer. Remote command execution. We built LXMFMonero—a system that sends Monero transactions over Reticulum, verified working over I2P and TCP testnets.

sections.title: Know the Limitations
sections.content:
Not Magic: Reticulum solves network problems, not physics problems.

Radio Still Has Physics

LoRa at 915 MHz gives you maybe 10km line-of-sight with good antennas. Vegetation, terrain, and buildings eat signal. HF can bounce worldwide, but it's slow and requires a license. Reticulum makes these links encrypted and routable—it doesn't make them faster or longer.

Low Bandwidth is Really Low

A LoRa link at SF10 gives you roughly 1 kbps. That's 125 bytes per second. Text messages: fine. Images: painful. Video: impossible. Design your applications accordingly.

No Anonymity Guarantee

Reticulum provides initiator anonymity in the protocol—packets don't contain source addresses. But if you're transmitting RF, you can be direction-found. For anonymity, route through I2P or use the network from locations you're not connected to.

Not Audited

The cryptography follows best practices, but Reticulum hasn't had a formal security audit. Don't use it for anything where a compromise means prison or death. Yet.

sections.title: Get Running in 5 Minutes
sections.content:
Install (Linux/macOS)

# Option 1: pipx (recommended)
pipx install rns

# Option 2: venv
python3 -m venv ~/.rns-venv
source ~/.rns-venv/bin/activate
pip install rns

Note: Direct pip install fails on most modern systems (PEP 668). Use pipx or a venv.

First run creates ~/.reticulum/config with a default AutoInterface. You're now a Reticulum node.

Verify

rnstatus

Connect to Public Network

Add to ~/.reticulum/config under [interfaces]:

[[RNS Testnet Amsterdam]]
  type = TCPClientInterface
  enabled = yes
  target_host = amsterdam.connect.reticulum.network
  target_port = 4965

Other active nodes: rns.beleth.net:4242, rns.chicagonomad.net:4242. Check rmap.world for live status.

Find the LFM Node

rnpath 2eabad04f9145d32a6a3eda285d66c39

Should return: Path found, destination is X hops away

Install NomadNet

pipx install nomadnet
nomadnet

Press Ctrl+L, paste 2eabad04f9145d32a6a3eda285d66c39, connect.

sections.title: How It Works (Condensed)
sections.content:
Identities

Ed25519 keypairs. Your public key hash is your address. 16 bytes, displayed as 32 hex characters.

Destinations

Addresses you can send to. Four types: Single (encrypted to one recipient), Group (symmetric key for multiple recipients), Plain (unencrypted broadcast), Link (established channels).

Announces

Nodes broadcast their presence periodically. Other nodes cache this information to build routing knowledge. No central directory—the network learns organically.

Links

Bidirectional encrypted channels between two identities. Three packets to establish (297 bytes total). Used for streaming data, file transfers, or interactive sessions.

Transport

Any node can forward packets for others by enabling transport. This extends network reach but isn't required. Most deployments need few transport nodes—too many degrades performance.
